author: Casandy420
body:
Maybe, but I think it might take longer than most people think. Tech firms sell to governments. Microsoft is one of the largest military contractors around the world. Pretty much every country's military runs windows.

Just listened to the q3 earnings call. Cloud demand is up like crazy right now. So, money is being shifted away from local resources into cloud computing resources. So many of AWS and Azure customers are shifting money into these tech companies. Smaller firms like NetApp, Atlassian, or Slack are seeing sales raise with this new demand.

&#x200B;

Also, there are entirely new markets for tech that weren't viable pre covid. Consider the NFL, NBA....I can't remember the sport, but they now use MSTeams. Companies are seeing the cost benefits of remote work. Virtual Formula 1 is another example. Things are going to be interesting. To stay competitive, you will need to piviot into this new economic situation. Red Robin is an interesting case study. They cut costs like crazy and embraced off site orders. Or look at Trupanion's 10K. They cut costs and increased cash on hand to a point where they can operate for an entire year w/o income.

&#x200B;

You have to remember that there are millions of dollars worth of human intelligence driving the decisions behind each of these Tickers. Boards are made up of people with way way way way more industry knowledge than anyone on reddit. Yes, Tesla exists, and a tweet can swing billions of dollars around the moon, but for the most part, companies are ran by intelligent folks trying their best to make money. That's it. Even if the world is on fire, these people will find a way to sell you insurance on credit. The economy has existed since before the old testament. Exodus 30:11-16  is just ancient hebrew tax law. Even if it's not money, people will find something to trade to create value. The wheel keeps on turning.

EDIT: Totally forgot, look at MSFT 10K. B2B OEM sales are the bread and butter. So you will need to see large retailers (including amazon) collapse before companies like intel and MSFT will feel the big hits.

Granted, I see both Intel and AMD getting a foothold into some of these markets as well. I think it’s the case that all of them can “win” and compete with Nvidia by offering more open solutions at lower cost. But it’s going to be a challenge for them for sure.

author: DARPA1191969v1
body:
I can give the perspective from a tech/software dev.

In my opinion, these are sort of different players. In fact, I would say that NVDA and AMD are far more analogous to each other than even AMD -> AAPL, and certainly to MSFT. The  way that I see it, NVDA/AMD are fundamentally companies that are concerned with producing a *physical good* \- literal chipsets and dies. AAPL seems to waver on the hardware side of things (they have been known to go proprietary in that arena, but have also loaned out work to INTC on more than one occasion). I most certainly see MSFT as a true software/PaaS/SaaS company - suffice to say that they are producing very little in the way of physical goods.

I think the *soft/hardware* direction is important to mention, because that fundamentally plays into the way that these companies deal in the market. Developing hardware is a mind-bendingly expensive process (relatively speaking). It takes years of R&D and cash on hand to fund something that is truly great. An example of this would be the move AMD made to Zen (which is based on the concept of 'chiplets'; highly-scalable many-core designs that are fundamentally different from their monolithic predecessors).

In terms of growth, I would have to say that I see two viable options here: *NVDA and MSFT*. MSFT is pretty easy to explain; they create a product that fundamentally has lower upstart costs (software development's most expensive attribute is the cost of human labor) and lower maintenance costs (I would think). There is some movement towards a more data-center driven profit scheme (which would require boots on ground hardware en masse), and Azure is certainly an AWS competitor, but I think we've yet to see them really go full throttle on that (I think it could be big if they did).

NVDA is a leader from a technological perspective. GPU compute-cores are very specialized devices that are good at doing only a few things, but very, *very well.* NVDA has been hammering away at this technology for years - they know the game, and they know where the money is. Autonomous cars, drones...the computer viz recogition software for postal, for literally anything, runs on a platform that is fundamentally a GPU (very high level view here). Machine learning applications in this field at the data-center level (think machine learning on AWS) are absolutely dominated by NVDA; In fact I would go as far as to say there aren't really a lot of competitors out there that are bringing to the table what NVDA does (Honestly AMD has severely gimped even their consumer dies at this point).

&#x200B;

I can elaborate more, but I'd go with MSFT and NVDA on this one.

author: _WhatchaDoin_
body:
I remember when AMD was at $2 back in 2016. All the talk in r/wsb, amazing that’s a $54 stock now. Can be explained by this:

INTC - PE 12x - 2% dividend

AMD - PE 125x - 0% dividend

Not sure of the upside on AMD to be honest. Even assuming that they grow 20% per year, it is going to take 10+ years for them to match INTC’s PE. I understand that PE is not everything, but I am not sure that will be a $600 Bn stock, 3 times INTC.

NVDA has cornered the GPU/AI market. INTC just need a great chipset to turn the tide on AMD.

author: mwani13
body:
Betting against hyper-growth stocks, even (if not especially) those that trade at crazy prices, is extremely tough and risky. These companies are often trading on a story. For better or for worse, sound financial analysis based on reasonable assumptions of future cash flows don’t necessarily matter for these stock prices. 

I would caution anyone from shorting a successful story—just look at the the TSLA bears who continue to get burned. 

I made money on NVDA and TSLA in the past. The toughest part is knowing when to jump off the train (if ever). I’m long INTC and I think that’s a great value play. It’s a defensible business with great profit margins. Somehow it trades pretty cheaply.

author: EpicCakeDay1
body:
Nvidia benefits from the current advances in machine learning, a bubble that's still got a couple years in it. They also don't have much in the way of competition.

Intel had AMD on life support for a decade. In the last year AMD has become competitive enough that Intel will have to compete again. That's good for consumers, and probably really bad for AMD. Since CPU prices are entirely artificial, Intel could easily drop their prices to compete in the budget computing market that AMD has recently claimed. It's really just a question of priorities and opportunity costs for Intel at this point.

author: LostThrowaway316
body:
>diy market is tiny and projected to decrease in revenue by over 30 percent.

Agreed. Decrease is only in the short term with possible recession and people being more money concious.

>Intel will catch up to AMD use on 7nm by end of 2020 and yes 7nm = 10nm. If use density metrics, Intel’s 10 nm is superior to AMD’s 7 nm. If you use TSMC’s marketing lingo, their process will be small as an atom in 5 years, then what???

Intel will not be on 7nm by the end of this year. Ice Lake JUST came out and it's only 10nm. They can't even make desktop/server 10nm yet; check out the new 10th gen desktop procs (Comet Lake is still 14nm). AMD Zen 3 is probably going to come out right ask Intel get their 10nm desktop/server chips going.

Regarding TSMCs 5nm (or 7nm EVU, however you want to call it), they've been working with Apple to use it on the next iPhone since January. That tech is pretty much confirmed and good to go, unlike anything on Intel's side.

>AMD’s margin is a lot smaller than Intel and contrary to people’s belief that Intel is discounting to be competitive with AMD, their financial and especially their gross margin does not reflect that.

AMD's margins are HUGE now, since they've moved everything to 7nm chiplet with a 12nm I/O die. They have a product stack that utilizes every single "waste" product to maximize production yield. They don't have to manufacture these huge dies with a bunch of cores anymore, since everything is based around dual, 4-core CCXs. All TSMC does is make tons of the same chip.

Actual yields are AMD at around 70% and Intel at around 35% (for their server stuff), and obviously not good enough to use on their consumer products.

author: Year3030
body:
I write complicated algos. Onetime I was like this is fucked, my algo was just losing money left and right. I wrote a simple one that just did a coin flip, it randomly went long / short with a TP and no SL. It performed drastically better than the complicated algo.

Lesson learned. This is why the story recently about the gorilla DD picking bananas at random had a better track record than market performance over 20 years made sense. You don't need fancy DD just some basic intel.

People are staying home? Get Dominos, Zoom, Amazon, all that shit makes sense. SDC? Ehh.. but why would they do any better now than previously? People aren't clamoring for dental treatment at home.

From a IT stand point amd has 5-8 years of dominate business ahead of them. We are purchasing all AMD processors from student devices to servers. Intel is not even on the radar anymore. AMD has built a very versatile platform for their current ryzen line of cpus that makes longevity of a home system much better as well. I  can replace my ryzen 5 2900 with a much newer ryzen 5 CPU and not have to change out my motherboard. 

A good friend of mine orders servers for a large data center "DOD centered but has a small consumer facing g side" and would typically order 200-300k worth of servers every year all with intel cpus. As of last year he is ordering amd. The cloud sector is key because they spend money not even batting a eye at it. 

My guess is amd $100 by 2023. Now keep in mind that due to virtualization hardware can be switched at a drop of a hat so when intel pulls its head out of its ass expect things to change fast.

author: ConfidenceFairy
body:
Intel took calculated risk in their attempt to get ahead without EUV lithography and it failed spectacularly. TSMC took EUV path and it turned out  fine. Had  EUV failed, TSMC would be now in ropes and Intel would soar. 

New lithography process transition is always a risk. Intel made a misstep and Global Foundries quit the 7nm game. TSMC or Samsung might fail in their next big process. AMD is now fully reliant on TSMC.

There is no reason to expect that Intel's next major process node tech is failure but it takes several years. I fully expect Intel to be fully back within 5 years with their new process and packaging. Until it's ready, they are refining the existing process technology and losing market share. AMD has few years to gain market share and grow into a big boy that takes on Intel as equal.

author: moldyjellybean
body:
People can spout Intel's demise all the want in the past when the only alternative was AMD's product and that was shit.  So when you don't innovate and your only other competitor makes a shit product and you do monopolistic tactics you're going to dominate. 

2017 brought an entirely different AMD.  So there's currently a way better alternative at the moment. And in 2021ish Apple is possibly going to drop Intel.

But don't short Intel. It's a stock is highly manipulated with tons of buybacks and other vehicles for it to be manipulated.  Instead invest in AMD.  

I don't know the technical investor stuff but having worked at a datacenter.  Intel's datacenter product is shit compared to even last years AMD datacenter offerings and AMD/TSMC is progressing to better things.  Intel is basically stagnant in a field that is always changing.

author: ubernat
body:
Not OP, but I bought AMD in 2013 and sold in 2020. I also have no proper financial background and based decisions on the internet lol 

It seemed like writing on the walls if you are into PC gaming. Reading forums and watching videos, people wanted AMD to be good, but it wasn't. AMD started hiring some big names too. 

Eventually, Nvidia and Intel start getting more and more incremental upgrades, then AMD sweeps in with some big changes.

author: labloke11
body:
First, $AMD has great marketing team. I have not heard anything positive news about Intel from either press or tech enthusiast, they are all about $AMD. This is free advertising, btw.


AMD is overvalued. They have provided low guidance for many quarters and their earning does not support your rosy scenario. One more thing, they meet their guidance almost exactly every quarter so do not expect earning surprises.

author: chinnick967
body: Intel is losing to AMD and is starting to fall behind, I wouldn't touch them until 2021

author: GreedySpeculator
body:
BUY THE DIP IN SEMIS IT S ALL GRANDSTANDING

  [https://www.wsj.com/articles/u-s-moves-to-cut-off-chip-supplies-to-huawei-11589545335](https://www.wsj.com/articles/u-s-moves-to-cut-off-chip-supplies-to-huawei-11589545335) 

The senior administration official played down the impact of the rule on Huawei. ‘This is a licensing requirement,” the official said. “It doesn’t necessarily mean things are denied.”

A year ago, Commerce Department officials put Huawei on an export blacklist of companies considered to be national-security threats. That move was designed to cut Huawei off from some U.S. semiconductor makers.

Over the last year, however, Huawei’s suppliers have largely [managed to get around the blacklisting ](https://www.wsj.com/articles/huawei-manages-to-make-smartphones-without-american-chips-11575196201?mod=article_inline&mod=article_inline)through a technicality. American companies—such as [Qualcomm](https://quotes.wsj.com/QCOM) Inc. and [Intel](https://quotes.wsj.com/INTC) Corp. —could still supply Huawei with some chips that are manufactured overseas. Huawei has also greatly ramped up the use of HiSilicon-designed chips, primarily built by TSMC, thereby reducing its reliance on the U.S. supply chain.

Huawei is now capable of building both 5G base-stations and advanced smartphones free of American technology, The Wall Street Journal reported in December.

author: bkorsedal
body: Ha ha ha, it was good until he went crypto.  I'm an engineer.  I design compture chips for Intel.  I know technology and crypto is a horrible, horrible system.

author: GromGrommeta
body:
QQQ would be the main one that auto-rebalances. SKYY is a hot one right now too that I do own.

But I run into the same issue as index funds except magnified. Tech funds might include a decent percentage of Twitter which I have no interest in owning. Or Intel/IBM, which might be fine for a retiree looking for yield but not a younger investor looking for growth.

author: No_volvere
body:
You lose your keys and cut off all your hair, another relaxing evenings at home.

2 days later you get a full socket set and a 12pk of chocolate bunnies from Amazon.
